721330f-a.text:
Madison Avenue, west side, between 43rd and 44th Streets. The headquarters of Pease & Elliman at 340 Madison Avenue will be demolished in 1926 and replaced by the National American Building,
about the same height.
The picture also shows detail of old St. Bartholomew's Church (1876), which will be taken down in 1919 to make room for Canadian Pacific Building. No. 338 on the left will be demolished at the same time.
1916.
Gift of E.M. Jenks.
Neg. #2634

721331f-a.text:
Madison Avenue, west side, from 44th to 43rd Streets, showing the Canadian Pacific Building in the later stages of construction, also showing construction of buildings at 43rd Street and remodelling of the Manhattan Hotel. The old building at 338 will be replaced by a modern structure of the same size (occupied in 1935 by a John David store). The Pease & Elliman Building at 340 will be replaced in 1927 by National American Building, the same size.
June 29, 1921
Underwood & Underwood, Photographer.
Gift of E.M. Jenks.

Neg #3904

721329f-a.text:
340 Madison Avenue, west side, between 43rd and 44th Streets, the National American Building, awarded first prize in the annual architectural contest of The Fifth Avenue Association. It replaced the old Pease & Elliman building, which was about the same size.
1927.
Wurts Brothers, Photographers.

1557974.title: 327-331 Madison Avenue - East 43rd Street
1557974.folder: 327-331 Madison Avenue - East 43rd Street, Manhattan, NY

721328f-a.text:
The Biltmore
Madison Avenue at 43rd Street, New York 17
“The Executive Hotel of New York”

The colorful new Guard Room is one of many attractive restaurants at the Biltmore in New York. Authentic regimental colors and armor are part of the unique decor.

Post Card
“Meet me under the clock at the Biltmore”

MADISON AVE. at 43rd ST., n.e. cor.

721332f-a.text:
Madison Avenue, east side, south from 44th to 43rd Street, showing
the newly built Canadian Pacific Building, No. 342.
The two small buildings, No. 336 and No. 340 (Pease & Ellman), will be replaced in 1927 by modern buildings of the same size.
1921.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.
